Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Exploring the Recluse Spider's Strong Nanometer-Thin Silk Ribbons
Award.AbstractNarration:
Non-technical Abstract
This CAREER award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to College of William and Mary is to investigate ribbon-like silk fiber of the brown recluse spider with respect to its hierarchical structure, and mechanical and adhesive properties, as well as its ability to form even stronger hybrid graphene-nanocomposite materials. Spider silks have outstanding strength and toughness; at the same time, they are naturally produced in a fully sustainable way, not using petroleum, large amounts of energy, or any toxic materials. As natural materials, they are also interesting for medical applications, such as implants. This combination of properties makes silks highly interesting as high performance materials. In this project, the investigator will study the silk of the brown recluse spider, which has a unique shape. In contrast to the other silk fibers, the filaments of the recluse are not cylindrical, but extremely flat and thin ribbons, resembling miniaturized pieces of sticky tape - ten times narrower and one thousand times thinner than a human hair. Previous studies by this researcher have shown that these ribbons share the outstanding mechanical properties with the best spider silks; at the same time, their unique shape gives rise to interesting new behavior, such as enhanced adhesion, and it allows the application of powerful analytical tools. Therefore, this project is expected to further our understanding of silks and their microstructure in general, and will reveal some of the unique properties of recluse silk in detail, such as their stickiness, and strength. This knowledge is a direct precursor to exploiting this exciting material for future engineering and biomedical applications. This project plans to provide participation and learning experiences for students from high school to graduate levels.


Technical Abstract

This CAREER award by the Biomaterials program in the Division of Materials Research to College of William and Mary is to investigate ribbon-like silk fiber of the brown recluse spider with respect to its hierarchical structure, and mechanical and adhesive properties, as well as its ability to form even stronger hybrid graphene-nanocomposite materials. Unlike many other synthetic or natural polymers, these silk fibers are freestanding, 50 nm-thin and 5 Ã¬m-wide protein ribbons. Previous studies by this researcher showed that the tensile performance rivals the strongest silks; at the same time, their unique morphology gives rise to novel properties and allows high-resolution structural characterization using atomic force microscopy. The structure of the recluse ribbons is simpler than other silks; a thin silk film with such outstanding strength is a novelty. Due to their thinness, these silk ribbons bend easily, which allows them to maximize the contact area with surfaces or objects they are in contact, enabling stronger van der Waals adhesion. The stickiness may further be enhanced by the nano-papillae, globular nanoscale surface features, and these features have not been observed in any other silks. The recluse ribbons would thus serve as a model system to improve our understanding of silks in general, and as a benchmark for biomedical silk films. The educational plan of this project is to provide research experiences to undergraduates from several disciplines; and special activities are planned to reach out to high school students. The research will be featured in new undergraduate and graduate classes making use of inverted learning techniques and digital technology.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Spider silk, the material spiders use to spin their webs, is fascinating because it is extremely strong, stiff, and tough. This material, made in a fully sustainable way by spiders, consists entirely of protein. It has long been believed that the outstanding properties of spider silk are due to its sophisticated structure, exhibiting characteristic features on many different length scales. In this project, we investigated the silk of the brown recluse spider, and have provided some unique insights into the structure of spider silk. With tailored experiments, we studied the structure of this silk at several different length scales and made it, in terms of its structure, the most well-understood of all spider silks.

We discovered that the recluse spider is the only one of over 48,000 spider species that spins thousands and thousands of tiny loops into its silk. To do this, it has an external spinneret that works somewhat like a sewing machine and rolls up the silk to form about fifteen loops per second. We found that by making these loops, the spider silk fibers become much tougher, meaning that they can absorb more energy before rupturing. We then studied whether the same concept could be used for man-made materials, in other words, whether humans can learn from spiders how to make tougher materials. We first analyzed this problem mathematically, and after it proved promising, we started a series of experiments. We used commercially available adhesive tapes and made some loops into these tapes. We found that, exactly as predicted, the loops made these tapes much tougher. Our models show that the toughness of a material can be enhanced ten times when enough loops are used.

Using high-resolution microscopes, we then showed for the first time that spider silk is entirely made of nanofibrils featuring a diameter less than one-millionth of an inch. Thus, somewhat like a rope, a spider silk fiber is made of thousands of thinner strands. We were able to determine the force at which each of these nanofibrils ruptures, and we now have a much better understanding of what makes spider silk fibers so extremely strong. This information will be critically important for the design of synthetic materials mimicking the outstanding performance of spider silk.

Our discovery on the importance of nanofibrils in silks made us curious to learn more about how spiders and other animals make them. We found out that the natural silk protein molecules have a built-in mechanism to self-organize into nanofibrils, which can be triggered by stirring the silk protein solution. We concluded that the same mechanism triggers the formation of nanofibrils when spiders and silkworms spin their silk fibers, which are hence mostly made of nanofibrils. This discovery is important for ongoing efforts to make synthetic spider silk with the same strength and toughness as their natural counterparts.

Through this project we gained important knowledge on design concepts for strong and tough materials, which can readily be implemented to make sustainable performance materials. Our results were widely disseminated with the scientific community through a large number of presentations at conferences and journal publications. Our results were also widely disseminated with the public through many appearances in the media, including television features, radio interviews, podcasts, and articles in magazines. We also provided opportunities for students from high schools, middle schools, elementary schools, and even pre-schools, to learn about our project, to get excited about science and engineering discplines, to visit our laboratory for hands-on activities, and to participate in our research through internships.
